metadata.title: Onboarding | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page covering onboarding best practices for apps and games across all Apple platforms. The document provides guidance on creating fast, fun, and optional onboarding experiences that teach through interactivity rather than instruction.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.
metadata.feedbackMethod: To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.

content.text: Onboarding
Onboarding can help people get a quick start using your app or game.

content.description: A stylized 3D illustration of an open cardboard box with an orange/amber color scheme. The box appears to be a shipping or moving box with folding flaps open at the top. The box has a warm orange-brown gradient coloring and casts a subtle shadow beneath it. The illustration style is clean, modern, and minimalist with soft shadows and rounded edges characteristic of Apple's design language.
content.composition: Centered single object against neutral background, box positioned at slight angle for dimensional effect
content.technicalDetails: 3D rendered illustration in Apple's contemporary design style
content.contextualRelevance: The open box metaphor represents the 'unboxing' experience of first launching an app or game - the moment of discovery and getting started. It visually reinforces the onboarding concept of introducing users to something new.

content.text: Ideally, people can understand your app or game simply by experiencing it, but if onboarding is necessary, design a flow that's fast, fun, and optional. When available, onboarding occurs after launching is complete â€” it isn't part of the launch experience.

internalLinks.context: Link to the Launching documentation page

content.text: Best practices

Teach through interactivity. People tend to grasp and retain information better when they can actually perform the task they're learning about instead of just viewing instructional material. As much as possible, provide an interactive onboarding experience where people can safely test an action, discover a feature, or try out a game mechanic.

Consider providing a collection of context-specific tips instead of a single onboarding flow. Integrating contextually relevant tips into your experience can help people learn about their current task while they make progress in your app or game. A context-specific tip can also help people learn better because it lets them concentrate on a single action or task before encountering new information. When you have instructional content that refers to a specific area of the interface, display these instructions near that area. For developer guidance, see TipKit.
content.boldLeadIn: Consider providing a collection of context-specific tips instead of a single onboarding flow.

internalLinks.context: Link to Apple's TipKit developer framework

content.text: If you need to present a prerequisite onboarding flow, design a brief, enjoyable experience that doesn't require people to memorize a lot of information. When onboarding is quick and entertaining, people are more likely to complete it. In contrast, if you try to teach too much, people can feel overwhelmed and may be less likely to remember what they learned.
content.boldLeadIn: If you need to present a prerequisite onboarding flow, design a brief, enjoyable experience that doesn't require people to memorize a lot of information.

content.text: If it makes sense to offer a separate tutorial, consider making it optional. If you let people skip the tutorial when they first launch your app or game, don't present it again on subsequent launches, but make sure it's easy for people to find if they want to view it later. For example, you could make the tutorial available in a help, account, or settings area within your app or game.
content.boldLeadIn: If it makes sense to offer a separate tutorial, consider making it optional.

content.text: Keep onboarding content focused on the experience you provide. People enter your onboarding flow to learn about your app or game; they don't need to learn how to use the system or the device.
content.boldLeadIn: Keep onboarding content focused on the experience you provide.

content.text: Additional content

Briefly display a splash screen if necessary. If you need to include a splash screen, design a beautiful graphic that communicates succinctly. Aim to display your splash screen just long enough for people to absorb the information at a glance without feeling that it's delaying their experience.
content.boldLeadIn: Briefly display a splash screen if necessary.

content.text: Don't let large downloads hinder onboarding. People want to start using your app or game immediately after first launching it, whether they participate in an onboarding flow or skip it. Consider including enough media and other content in your software package to prevent people from having to wait for downloads to complete before they can start interacting with your app or game. For guidance, see Launching.
content.boldLeadIn: Don't let large downloads hinder onboarding.

internalLinks.context: Link to the Launching documentation page

content.text: Avoid displaying licensing details within your onboarding flow. Let the App Store display agreements and disclaimers so people can read them before downloading your app or game. If you must include these items within the onboarding flow, integrate them in a balanced way that doesn't disrupt the experience.
content.boldLeadIn: Avoid displaying licensing details within your onboarding flow.

content.text: Additional requests

Postpone nonessential setup flows or customization steps. Provide reasonable default settings so most people can immediately start interacting with your app or game without performing additional configuration.
content.boldLeadIn: Postpone nonessential setup flows or customization steps.

content.text: If your app or game needs access to private data or resources before it can function, consider integrating the permission request into your onboarding flow. In this scenario, making the request during your onboarding flow gives you the opportunity to show people why your app or game needs their permission and the benefits of granting it. Otherwise, present a permission request when people first access the specific function that relies on private data or resources. For guidance, see Requesting permission.
content.boldLeadIn: If your app or game needs access to private data or resources before it can function, consider integrating the permission request into your onboarding flow.

internalLinks.context: Link to the Requesting permission documentation page

content.text: Prefer letting people experience your app or game before prompting them for ratings or purchases. People can be more likely to respond positively to such requests when they've had a chance to become engaged with your app or game.
content.boldLeadIn: Prefer letting people experience your app or game before prompting them for ratings or purchases.

content.text: Platform considerations
No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

Related

content.text: Change log

cells.content: Clarified different approaches to onboarding and added a guideline on displaying a splash screen.
Updated to include guidance for visionOS.

content.tableSummary: Document revision history showing two updates: June 2024 added splash screen guidance and clarified onboarding approaches; June 2023 added visionOS platform support.

content.description: Toggle buttons for switching between light mode, dark mode, and auto (system) theme

pages.pageSummary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for Onboarding. The page provides comprehensive guidance on creating effective onboarding experiences for apps and games across all Apple platforms. Key recommendations include teaching through interactivity, using context-specific tips via TipKit, keeping onboarding brief and optional, avoiding licensing details, postponing non-essential setup, integrating permission requests thoughtfully, and delaying rating/purchase prompts. The page includes links to related WWDC videos and a change log showing updates in June 2024 and June 2023.

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Apple Developer navigation bar with News, Discover, Design, Develop, Distribute, Support, Account links
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Comprehensive site footer with Platforms, Topics & Technologies, Resources, Support, Account, Programs, and Events sections

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces onboarding as a way to help users quickly start using apps/games, emphasizing that it should be fast, fun, and optional.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Five key practices: teach through interactivity, use context-specific tips with TipKit, keep prerequisite flows brief, make tutorials optional, and focus content on the app experience rather than system/device usage.

sections.title: Additional content
sections.summary: Three guidelines for additional content: use brief splash screens if needed, avoid large downloads blocking onboarding, and keep licensing details out of the onboarding flow.

sections.title: Additional requests
sections.summary: Three guidelines for requests during onboarding: postpone non-essential setup, integrate permission requests when functionally required, and delay rating/purchase prompts until users are engaged.

sections.title: Platform considerations
sections.summary: States that no additional platform-specific considerations exist for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to Launching, Feedback, and Offering help documentation pages.

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Three WWDC video recommendations: Discoverable design, Designing Award Winning Apps and Games, Love at First Launch.

sections.summary: Provides related documentation links and recommended WWDC videos for further learning.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history with two entries: June 2024 (splash screen guidance, onboarding clarifications) and June 2023 (visionOS support).

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG documentation structure: it opens with a title, subtitle, and hero illustration establishing the topic. The introduction provides the core philosophy (onboarding should be fast, fun, optional). Best practices form the primary guidance section with detailed recommendations. Additional content and additional requests sections cover supplementary concerns. Platform considerations confirms universal applicability. Resources provide further learning paths. The change log documents revision history.

keyTerms.definition: A flow that helps people get a quick start using an app or game, occurring after launching is complete
Apple's framework for providing context-specific tips in apps
A beautiful graphic displayed briefly to communicate information succinctly during app launch or onboarding
Instructional content integrated contextually into the app experience, displayed near the relevant interface area
An onboarding sequence that must be completed before users can access the main app functionality
A separate instructional experience that can be offered optionally and made available later in help/settings areas

keyFindings: Onboarding should be fast, fun, and optional - not part of the launch experience
Interactive onboarding where users perform tasks is more effective than passive instruction
Context-specific tips via TipKit can replace single onboarding flows for better learning
Prerequisite onboarding should be brief and not require memorizing lots of information
Optional tutorials should not re-present on subsequent launches but remain accessible in settings/help
Onboarding content should focus on the app experience, not system/device usage
Splash screens should be brief and beautiful, communicating at a glance
Large downloads should not block users from starting to interact with the app
Licensing details should be displayed on App Store, not in onboarding flow
Non-essential setup/customization should be postponed with reasonable defaults provided
Permission requests can be integrated into onboarding when functionally required, with explanation of benefits
Rating and purchase prompts should wait until users have engaged with the app
All guidelines apply equally to iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS

relatedVideos: Designing Award Winning Apps and Games

designDecisions.decision: Onboarding occurs after launching, not during
designDecisions.rationale: Launch experience should be instant; onboarding is a separate, optional flow

designDecisions.decision: Prefer interactive learning over instructional viewing
designDecisions.rationale: People grasp and retain information better when performing tasks

designDecisions.decision: Use context-specific tips instead of single onboarding flow
designDecisions.rationale: Lets users concentrate on one action/task at a time, learn while making progress
Respects user choice; avoids re-presenting on subsequent launches
App Store already handles agreements/disclaimers before download
Allows immediate app interaction without additional configuration
Users respond more positively after becoming engaged with the app
